lines.text: Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Speak, speak.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Resolved. resolved.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: We knowt, we knowt.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Let us kill him, and well have corn at our own price. Ist a verdict

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: No more talking ont let it be done: away, away!

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: One word, good citizens.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority surfeits on would relieve us: if they would yield us but the superfluity, while it were wholesome, we might guess they relieved us humanely but they think we are too dear: the leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularise their abundance our sufferance is a gain to them Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes: for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Against him first: hes a very dog to the commonalty.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: Consider you what services he has done for his country

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Very well and could be content to give him good report fort, but that he pays himself with being proud.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end: though softconscienced men can be content to say it was for his country he did it to please his mother and to be partly proud which he is, even till the altitude of his virtue.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition. What shouts are these The other side o the city is risen: why stay we prating here to the Capitol!
Shouts within

lines.speaker: all
lines.text: Come, come.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Soft! who comes here
Enter MENENIUS AGRIPPA

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: Worthy Menenius Agrippa one that hath always loved the people.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Hes one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What works, my countrymen, in hand where go you With bats and clubs The matter speak, I pray you.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Our business is not unknown to the senate they have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now well show em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths: they shall know we have strong arms too.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours, Will you undo yourselves

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I tell you, friends, most charitable care Have the patricians of you. For your wants, Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them Against the Roman state, whose course will on The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs Of more strong link asunder than can ever Appear in your impediment. For the dearth, The gods, not the patricians, make it, and Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack, You are transported by calamity Thither where more attends you, and you slander The helms o the state, who care for you like fathers, When you curse them as enemies.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Care for us! True, indeed! They neer cared for us yet: suffer us to famish, and their storehouses crammed with grain make edicts for usury, to support usurers repeal daily any wholesome act established against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will and theres all the love they bear us.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Either you must Confess yourselves wondrous malicious, Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture To stale t a little more.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Well, Ill hear it, sir: yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, an t please you, deliver.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: There was a time when all the bodys members Rebelld against the belly, thus accused it: That only like a gulf it did remain I the midst o the body, idle and unactive, Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel, And, mutually participate, did minister Unto the appetite and affection common Of the whole body. The belly answerd

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Well, sir, what answer made the belly

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile, Which neer came from the lungs, but even thus For, look you, I may make the belly smile As well as speakit tauntingly replied To the discontented members, the mutinous parts That envied his receipt even so most fitly As you malign our senators for that They are not such as you.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Your bellys answer What! The kinglycrowned head, the vigilant eye, The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier, Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter. With other muniments and petty helps In this our fabric, if that they

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What then Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then what then

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Should by the cormorant belly be restraind, Who is the sink o the body,

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Well, what then

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: The former agents, if they did complain, What could the belly answer

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I will tell you If youll bestow a smallof what you have little Patience awhile, youll hear the bellys answer.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Yere long about it.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Note me this, good friend Your most grave belly was deliberate, Not rash like his accusers, and thus answerd: True is it, my incorporate friends, quoth he, That I receive the general food at first, Which you do live upon and fit it is, Because I am the storehouse and the shop Of the whole body: but, if you do remember, I send it through the rivers of your blood, Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o the brain And, through the cranks and offices of man, The strongest nerves and small inferior veins From me receive that natural competency Whereby they live: and though that all at once, You, my good friends,this says the belly, mark me,

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Ay, sir well, well.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Though all at once cannot See what I do deliver out to each, Yet I can make my audit up, that all From me do back receive the flour of all, And leave me but the bran. What say you tot

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: It was an answer: how apply you this

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: The senators of Rome are this good belly, And you the mutinous members for examine Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly Touching the weal o the common, you shall find No public benefit which you receive But it proceeds or comes from them to you And no way from yourselves. What do you think, You, the great toe of this assembly

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: I the great toe! why the great toe

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: For that, being one o the lowest, basest, poorest, Of this most wise rebellion, thou gost foremost: Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run, Leadst first to win some vantage. But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs: Rome and her rats are at the point of battle The one side must have bale. Hail, noble Marcius!
Enter CAIUS MARCIUS

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Thanks. Whats the matter, you dissentious rogues, That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, Make yourselves scabs

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: We have ever your good word.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: He that will give good words to thee will flatter Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs, That like nor peace nor war the one affrights you, The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you, Where he should find you lions, finds you hares Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no, Than is the coal of fire upon the ice, Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is To make him worthy whose offence subdues him And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness Deserves your hate and your affections are A sick mans appetite, who desires most that Which would increase his evil. He that depends Upon your favours swims with fins of lead And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust Ye With every minute you do change a mind, And call him noble that was now your hate, Him vile that was your garland. Whats the matter, That in these several places of the city You cry against the noble senate, who, Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else Would feed on one another Whats their seeking

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: For corn at their own rates whereof, they say, The city is well stored.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Hang em! They say! Theyll sit by the fire, and presume to know Whats done i the Capitol whos like to rise, Who thrives and who declines side factions and give out Conjectural marriages making parties strong And feebling such as stand not in their liking Below their cobbled shoes. They say theres grain enough! Would the nobility lay aside their ruth, And let me use my sword, Ill make a quarry With thousands of these quarterd slaves, as high As I could pick my lance.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded For though abundantly they lack discretion, Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you, What says the other troop

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: They are dissolved: hang em! They said they were anhungry sighd forth proverbs, That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat, That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds They vented their complainings which being answerd, And a petition granted them, a strange one To break the heart of generosity, And make bold power look palethey threw their caps As they would hang them on the horns o the moon, Shouting their emulation.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What is granted them

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms, Of their own choice: ones Junius Brutus, Sicinius Velutus, and I know notSdeath! The rabble should have first unroofd the city, Ere so prevaild with me: it will in time Win upon power and throw forth greater themes For insurrections arguing.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: This is strange.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Go, get you home, you fragments!
Enter a Messenger, hastily

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Wheres Caius Marcius

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Here: whats the matter

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: I am glad on t: then we shall ha means to vent Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders. Enter COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Marcius, tis true that you have lately told us The Volsces are in arms.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: They have a leader, Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to t. I sin in envying his nobility, And were I any thing but what I am, I would wish me only he.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: You have fought together.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Were half to half the world by the ears and he. Upon my party, Ild revolt to make Only my wars with him: he is a lion That I am proud to hunt.

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Then, worthy Marcius, Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: It is your former promise.

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Sir, it is And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus face. What, art thou stiff standst out

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: No, Caius Marcius Ill lean upon one crutch and fight with tother, Ere stay behind this business.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: O, truebred!

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: Your company to the Capitol where, I know, Our greatest friends attend us.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: [To COMINIUS]                Lead you on. Right worthy you priority.
To MARCIUS

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Noble Marcius!

lines.speaker: first senator
lines.text: [To the Citizens]  Hence to your homes be gone!

lines.speaker: marcius
lines.text: Nay, let them follow: The Volsces have much corn take these rats thither To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners, Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow.
Citizens steal away. Exeunt all but SICINIUS and BRUTUS

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: He has no equal.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Markd you his lip and eyes

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Nay. but his taunts.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Bemock the modest moon.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The present wars devour him: he is grown Too proud to be so valiant.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Such a nature, Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder His insolence can brook to be commanded Under Cominius.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Fame, at the which he aims, In whom already hes well graced, can not Better be held nor more attaind than by A place below the first: for what miscarries Shall be the generals fault, though he perform To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure Will then cry out of Marcius O if he Had borne the business!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Besides, if things go well, Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall Of his demerits rob Cominius.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Come: Half all Cominius honours are to Marcius. Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed In aught he merit not.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Lets hence, and hear How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion, More than his singularity, he goes Upon this present action.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lets along.
Exeunt
